repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Second Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project for West Bank and Gaza
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: There is a need to be flexible and
            responsive with respect to sub-project selection and
            procurement arrangements-simplifying procedures and
            decentralizing responsibility to the extent possible. The
            issue related to lack of local contribution for water
            connections in Bidya underlines the importance of obtaining
            firm commitments from local partners prior to implementing
            components that depend on their inputs. Significant capacity
            building can be achieved even during crisis and, in fact,
            partly because of crisis. The experience with the accounting
            systems reform over two projects (MIDP-1 and 2) demonstrates
            that significant learning can take place. Significant
            progress can be made even in a very difficult environment if
            adequate local leadership exists. Building good Monitoring
            and Evaluation System including relevant set of indicators
            that enables proper monitoring, regular updating and
            capabilities of assessing impacts of projects.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Second Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Municipal Infrastructure
            Development Project in the West Bank and Gaza, builds on the
            on-going municipal development operation, and, focuses on
            high priority infrastructure rehabilitation, and municipal
            capacity building. The components will: 1) support physical
            improvement, and rehabilitation of regional roads, as well
            as village, and municipal water supply, and sewerage works.
            It includes two sub-components which provide technical
            assistance for the design, and supervision of works; 2)
            support capacity building in the Ministry of Public Works
            (MPW), through the development of road maintenance programs,
            and local government capacity building. Sub-components
            include accounting systems reform, and development programs
            for selected municipalities; 3) provide essential
            operational support to MPW, and to the Ministry of Local
            Government, through improved monitoring, administrative, and
            reporting practices.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Second Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project : environmental
            management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This Environmental Management Plan has
            been prepared to integrate environmental concerns into the
            design, and implementation of the Second Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project, and will support
            adequate roads site selection, and assess water network
            subprojects. This includes staff, and contractors training
            during implementation, and, community involvement in
            monitoring environmental impacts as a result of
            construction. Mitigating measures address: 1) the
            establishment of guidelines, and specifications for
            contractors to control waste disposal, and safety hazards,
            and enforce environmental, and traffic regulations; 2) soil
            erosion should be contained, through the installation of
            guard rails, with reflectors, and proper compaction of
            shoulders. Re-vegetation, particularly replanting of trees,
            should take place, as road widening, and improvements
            require uprooting of existing vegetation; 3) construction,
            and maintenance of drainage ditches should prevent clogging,
            caused by erosion, and improper drainage; 4) increased
            separation of wastewater from consumption waters, to prevent
            health hazards resulting from inadequate sanitation, and
            improper sewage, and sludge disposal. Capacity building,
            training, and contingency budget are included to sustain
            environmental protection.
